questions.stem: According to Standard 10.01 (Informed Consent to Therapy), psychologists obtain informed consent to therapy as early as is feasible in the therapeutic relationship. When a psychologist is court-ordered to provide therapy to a mandated client, informed consent must still address:

options.text: Only the client's right to refuse treatment entirely
The nature and anticipated course of therapy, fees, involvement of third parties, limits of confidentiality, and the mandated nature of the treatment
Only the fees and billing arrangements because the client has no choice about attending
Nothing, because mandated clients cannot truly consent and therefore informed consent is waived

questions.explanation: Standard 10.01(a) requires informed consent to therapy that includes the nature and anticipated course of therapy, fees, involvement of third parties, and limits of confidentiality. Even when therapy is mandated, the psychologist must still provide informed consent. Standard 10.01(c) specifically addresses mandated therapy, requiring the psychologist to inform the individual about the mandated nature of treatment, limits of confidentiality, and any other relevant issues at the outset. The mandated nature of treatment does not eliminate the obligation to inform the client about the therapeutic process.

questions.stem: A psychologist providing couples therapy learns during a joint session that one partner intends to file for divorce and has already retained an attorney, but has not yet told the other partner. The psychologist had established a no-secrets policy at the outset of treatment. Under Standard 10.02 (Therapy Involving Couples or Families), the psychologist should:

options.text: Immediately disclose the divorce plans to the other partner
Refer to the no-secrets policy established at the outset and work with the disclosing partner on how to address this information within the therapeutic context
Terminate therapy immediately without explanation
Secretly meet with each partner individually to gather more information before deciding

questions.explanation: Standard 10.02 requires that the psychologist clarify at the outset which individuals are clients, the relationship the psychologist will have with each person, the roles of the psychologist, and the probable uses of the services or information obtained. Having established a no-secrets policy at the start of treatment, the psychologist should refer to this agreement and work therapeutically with the disclosing partner on addressing this information within therapy. This maintains the integrity of the established therapeutic framework while respecting the therapeutic process. Immediate disclosure, termination without process, or secret individual meetings would all undermine the therapeutic relationship and the established treatment agreement.

questions.stem: Standard 10.05 (Sexual Intimacies With Current Therapy Clients/Patients) states that psychologists do not engage in sexual intimacies with current therapy clients/patients. A client expresses strong romantic feelings toward their therapist, and the therapist realizes they are also attracted to the client. Under Standard 10.05, the most appropriate action is:

options.text: Terminate therapy immediately and begin a romantic relationship after a waiting period
Acknowledge the feelings in supervision or consultation, maintain appropriate boundaries, and consider whether a referral is needed while continuing to prioritize the client's welfare
Disclose mutual attraction to the client and allow the client to decide whether to continue therapy or pursue a relationship
Continue therapy while gradually allowing the relationship to become more personal outside of sessions

questions.explanation: Standard 10.05 absolutely prohibits sexual intimacies with current therapy clients. When a psychologist experiences attraction to a client, the ethical obligation is to seek consultation or supervision, maintain professional boundaries, and evaluate whether the therapeutic relationship can be maintained without compromise to the client's care. If the therapist's objectivity is impaired, referral to another competent provider is appropriate. Terminating to pursue a romantic relationship would be exploitative. Disclosing mutual attraction could be experienced as coercive given the power differential. Allowing boundary erosion violates multiple ethical standards. The focus must remain on the client's welfare and therapeutic needs.

questions.stem: A psychologist has been treating a client for major depressive disorder for two years. The client has shown significant improvement and the psychologist believes the client has met treatment goals. Under Standard 10.10 (Terminating Therapy), the psychologist should:

options.text: Abruptly end treatment at the next session to avoid dependency
Discuss the client's progress, engage in a collaborative termination process, provide appropriate pre-termination counseling, and offer referrals if additional services may be needed
Continue therapy indefinitely because termination might cause the client distress
End therapy without discussing it with the client to avoid an emotional reaction

questions.explanation: Standard 10.10(a) states that psychologists terminate therapy when it becomes reasonably clear that the client no longer needs the service, is not likely to benefit, or is being harmed by continued service. Standard 10.10(c) requires psychologists to provide pre-termination counseling and suggest alternative service providers as appropriate. Termination should be a collaborative, therapeutic process that reinforces the client's gains, addresses concerns about ending, and ensures continuity of care if needed. Abrupt termination, indefinite continuation when goals are met, or ending without discussion all violate the standard's requirements for thoughtful, client-centered termination.

questions.stem: Standard 10.08 (Sexual Intimacies With Former Therapy Clients/Patients) establishes a minimum waiting period after therapy termination before a sexual relationship may be considered. This minimum period is:

options.text: Six months
One year
Two years, and even then only under the most unusual circumstances
Five years

questions.explanation: Standard 10.08(a) prohibits psychologists from engaging in sexual intimacies with former clients for at least two years after cessation or termination of therapy. Standard 10.08(b) further specifies that even after two years, sexual intimacies with former clients are permitted only in the most unusual circumstances. The psychologist who engages in such a relationship after the two-year period bears the burden of demonstrating that there has been no exploitation, considering factors such as: the amount of time that has passed, the nature and duration of therapy, circumstances of termination, the client's personal history, the client's current mental status, likelihood of adverse impact, and whether the psychologist suggested or implied the possibility of a post-termination relationship during therapy.

questions.stem: Standard 10.01 (Informed Consent to Therapy) requires psychologists to inform clients about several aspects of therapy. Which of the following are required elements? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The nature and anticipated course of therapy
Fees and billing arrangements
A guarantee of specific therapeutic outcomes
The limits of confidentiality, including mandatory reporting obligations
The involvement of third parties, such as insurance companies or supervisors, and the extent of their access to information

questions.explanation: Standard 10.01 requires informed consent that includes: the nature and anticipated course of therapy (A), fees (B), limits of confidentiality (D), and third-party involvement (E). Guaranteeing specific outcomes (C) would be unethical because therapeutic outcomes depend on many factors and cannot be promised. Informed consent in therapy is an ongoing process, not a one-time event, and must be revisited as circumstances change. The standard also addresses special populations, including those legally incapable of consent (10.01(b)) and mandated clients (10.01(c)).

questions.stem: Under Standard 10.02 (Therapy Involving Couples or Families), which ethical considerations must the psychologist address at the outset of treatment? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Clarifying which individuals are the clients in the therapeutic relationship
Explaining the psychologist's role and relationship with each person involved
Discussing how information will be handled, including policies on individual disclosures
Promising that everything shared by each individual will remain secret from the other partner or family members
Addressing potential conflicts between the needs of different family members and how they will be managed

questions.explanation: Standard 10.02 requires psychologists to: clarify who the clients are (A) — the individual, the couple, or the family unit; explain their role with each person (B); discuss information management policies (C), including whether a no-secrets policy or individual confidentiality policy will apply; and address potential conflicts between participants (E). Promising absolute secrecy for individual disclosures (D) is not required and, depending on the therapeutic model, may actually be inadvisable. The key obligation is transparency about how the psychologist will handle these complex relational dynamics.

questions.stem: Standard 10.10 (Terminating Therapy) addresses several situations in which therapy may or should be terminated. In which of the following circumstances is termination ethically appropriate? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: When it becomes reasonably clear that the client no longer needs the service
When the client is not likely to benefit from continued therapy
When the psychologist is threatened or endangered by the client or a person with whom the client has a relationship
Whenever the psychologist becomes bored with the client's presenting problem
When continued therapy would be harmful to the client

questions.explanation: Standard 10.10 permits or requires termination when: the client no longer needs services (A, Standard 10.10(a)); the client is not likely to benefit (B, Standard 10.10(a)); the psychologist is threatened or endangered (C, Standard 10.10(b)); or continued service is harmful (E, Standard 10.10(a)). Boredom with a client (D) is not an ethical basis for termination — it reflects a countertransference issue that should be addressed through consultation or supervision. Standard 10.10(c) also requires pre-termination counseling and referrals as clinically appropriate.

questions.stem: A client requests that their psychologist begin seeing their adult child for individual therapy as well. Under Standard 10.02 and related provisions, which considerations apply? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The psychologist must consider whether providing therapy to both individuals could impair objectivity or effectiveness
The psychologist must consider the risk of conflicting loyalties and information management challenges
There is no ethical concern because the client requested the arrangement
If the psychologist proceeds, they must clarify roles, confidentiality boundaries, and potential conflicts at the outset with both clients
The psychologist should consider whether referral to another provider would better serve the adult child's therapeutic needs

questions.explanation: Providing individual therapy to two closely related individuals creates significant ethical complexity. The psychologist must consider: potential impairment of objectivity (A, Standard 3.05); conflicting loyalties and information management (B); clarification of roles and confidentiality if proceeding (D, Standard 10.02); and whether referral would better serve the new client (E). A client's request (C) does not eliminate the ethical concerns — the psychologist's professional judgment must prevail. The multiple relationship risks (hearing conflicting accounts, divided loyalties, potential breaches of confidentiality) often favor referral to another provider.

questions.stem: Under Standard 10.04 (Providing Therapy to Those Served by Others), when a psychologist is asked to provide therapy to a person already receiving mental health services from another professional, the psychologist should: (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Carefully consider the treatment issues and the potential client's welfare
Discuss these issues with the client to minimize the risk of confusion and conflict
Begin therapy immediately because clients have the right to see any provider they choose
Consult with the other service provider when appropriate and with proper authorization
Consider whether the involvement of multiple providers could be harmful or confusing to the client

questions.explanation: Standard 10.04 requires psychologists to: carefully consider treatment issues and client welfare (A); discuss these issues with the client (B); and minimize confusion and conflict. While clients do have the right to choose providers, the psychologist cannot simply begin therapy without considering the implications (C is incorrect). Appropriate steps include consulting with the other provider when authorized (D) and evaluating whether multiple providers could create harm or confusion (E). The goal is coordinated care that serves the client's best interests, not fragmented or conflicting treatment approaches.

questions.stem: Match each therapy scenario to the Standard 10 provision it most directly implicates:

rows.text: A psychologist begins a sexual relationship with a current therapy client who says they consent to the relationship
A psychologist starts treating a new client who is already in individual therapy with another psychologist, without considering the impact on the client's existing treatment
A psychologist initiates a romantic relationship with a former client 6 months after terminating therapy
A psychologist abruptly terminates therapy with a suicidal client because the client's insurance has run out, without providing referrals or pre-termination counseling

columns.text: Standard 10.04: Providing Therapy to Those Served by Others
Standard 10.05: Sexual Intimacies With Current Clients
Standard 10.08: Sexual Intimacies With Former Clients

questions.explanation: Sexual relationship with current client = Standard 10.05 (always prohibited regardless of claimed consent; power differential makes genuine consent impossible). Treating a client already in therapy without considering impact = Standard 10.04 (requires careful consideration of treatment issues). Romance with former client at 6 months = Standard 10.08 (violates the minimum two-year waiting period). Abrupt termination of suicidal client without referrals = Standard 10.10 (requires pre-termination counseling and referrals; abandonment of a high-risk client is a serious ethical violation).

questions.stem: Match each Standard 10 provision to the primary client welfare concern it addresses:

rows.text: Standard 10.05: Sexual Intimacies With Current Clients

columns.text: Ensuring clients can make autonomous, informed decisions about their treatment
Protecting clients from exploitation of the power differential inherent in the therapeutic relationship
Ensuring continuity of care when the therapist is unavailable due to illness, relocation, or other factors
Protecting all participants' welfare and clarifying expectations about confidentiality among group members

questions.explanation: Standard 10.01 (Informed Consent) protects client autonomy through informed decision-making about treatment (col1). Standard 10.03 (Group Therapy) addresses the unique responsibility to protect all group members and clarify that the therapist cannot guarantee other members will maintain confidentiality (col4). Standard 10.05 (Sexual Intimacies) directly addresses the exploitation risk created by the therapist-client power differential (col2). Standard 10.09 (Interruption of Therapy) addresses continuity of care when therapy is interrupted by factors such as therapist illness, relocation, client relocation, or financial limitations (col3).

questions.stem: For each therapy modality, select ALL unique ethical considerations that apply under Standard 10:

columns.text: Must clarify who is the identified client
Cannot guarantee that other participants will maintain confidentiality
Must establish policies about how individual disclosures will be handled
Must address potential conflicts between participants' competing interests
Informed consent must include the nature, purpose, and anticipated course of treatment

questions.explanation: Individual therapy: Standard informed consent (10.01) applies. Couples/family therapy (10.02): Must clarify who is the client (col1), establish individual disclosure policies (col3), address competing interests (col4), and obtain informed consent (col5). Group therapy (10.03): Must clarify the client relationship (col1), address that confidentiality cannot be guaranteed among group members (col2), manage competing interests (col4), and obtain informed consent (col5). The complexity of ethical obligations increases with the number of participants involved in the therapeutic process.

questions.stem: For each termination scenario, select ALL ethical obligations the psychologist must fulfill:

rows.text: Client has achieved treatment goals and no longer needs services
Client is being threatened or endangered by someone in the client's life and the psychologist feels unsafe
Psychologist is relocating to another state

columns.text: Offer appropriate referrals to other service providers
Discuss the client's progress and reinforce therapeutic gains
May terminate without pre-termination counseling if safety concerns warrant it
Make reasonable efforts to facilitate continuation of care

questions.explanation: Goal achievement (row1): Pre-termination counseling (10.10(c)), referrals as appropriate, and reinforcing progress are all standard termination practices. Safety concerns (row2): Standard 10.10(b) permits termination when the psychologist is threatened or endangered; while referrals should be attempted, pre-termination counseling may not be feasible or safe. Relocation (row3): Standard 10.09 addresses interruption of therapy, requiring reasonable efforts to facilitate continuation of care, pre-termination counseling, referrals, and discussion of progress. The psychologist has a heightened obligation to ensure continuity when they initiate the termination.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 10.01 (Informed Consent to Therapy):

According to Standard 10.01, psychologists obtain informed consent for therapy as early as is [BLANK1] in the therapeutic relationship. This includes informing clients about the nature and anticipated course of therapy, [BLANK2], and the limits of confidentiality. When working with persons who are legally incapable of giving consent, psychologists still provide an appropriate [BLANK3] and seek the person's assent to the extent possible. When therapy is [BLANK4] by a court or other authority, the psychologist must inform the client about the mandated nature of treatment and its implications. Informed consent in therapy is an [BLANK5] process, not a one-time event.
questions.explanation: Standard 10.01 requires informed consent as early as feasible, covering therapy nature, fees and billing, and confidentiality limits. For legally incapable persons, an appropriate explanation must be provided and assent sought. For mandated therapy (10.01(c)), the mandated nature must be explicitly disclosed. Informed consent is understood as an ongoing process that evolves as treatment progresses, new issues emerge, and circumstances change. This ongoing nature distinguishes informed consent from a simple administrative procedure.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about sexual boundaries in therapy under Standard 10:

Standard 10.05 absolutely prohibits sexual intimacies with [BLANK1] therapy clients. Standard 10.06 extends this prohibition to sexual intimacies with [BLANK2] of current therapy clients. Standard 10.07 states that psychologists do not accept as therapy clients persons with whom they have [BLANK3]. Standard 10.08 establishes that psychologists do not engage in sexual intimacies with former clients for at least [BLANK4] after termination, and even then only under the most unusual circumstances where the psychologist bears the [BLANK5] of demonstrating that no exploitation has occurred.
questions.explanation: Standards 10.05 through 10.08 create a comprehensive framework addressing sexual boundaries in therapy. 10.05 prohibits sexual intimacies with current clients. 10.06 extends the prohibition to relatives and significant others of current clients. 10.07 prohibits accepting former sexual partners as therapy clients, recognizing the impossibility of objective treatment. 10.08 establishes a minimum two-year waiting period after termination, and even then the psychologist bears the burden of proving no exploitation occurred. Together, these standards recognize the power differential inherent in therapy and protect clients from sexual exploitation.

questions.stem: A psychologist has been providing individual therapy to a client with borderline personality disorder for 18 months. The client's insurance coverage has ended, and the client cannot afford to pay out of pocket. The client is currently in a period of instability, with recent self-harm behavior and expressed suicidal ideation. The psychologist is considering whether to terminate or continue treatment.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 10 provision is most directly relevant to this dilemma?

options.text: The client is currently at elevated risk for self-harm and suicide
Abrupt termination could be experienced as abandonment, exacerbating borderline symptoms
The therapeutic alliance has been established over 18 months and is a key treatment factor
The psychologist's financial needs justify immediate termination regardless of client risk
Provide pre-termination counseling that includes safety planning and crisis resources
Explore reduced-fee or sliding-scale options, community mental health resources, or pro bono continuation during the transition
Terminate immediately because therapy cannot continue without payment
Facilitate a warm transfer to another provider, including coordination of care and sharing of relevant treatment information with consent

centerOptions.text: Standard 10.05: Sexual Intimacies With Current Clients
Standard 10.04: Providing Therapy to Those Served by Others

questions.explanation: Standard 10.10 (Terminating Therapy) is most relevant. While financial limitations can make termination necessary, the standard requires that psychologists not abandon clients. Standard 10.10(c) requires pre-termination counseling and referrals. Given the client's current risk level (self-harm, suicidal ideation), immediate termination without a safety net could constitute abandonment and cause serious harm. The psychologist must balance practical financial realities with the ethical obligation to ensure continuity of care, especially for a high-risk client. Appropriate actions include safety planning, exploring alternative arrangements, and facilitating a careful transition to another provider.

questions.stem: A therapist who has been treating a client for PTSD for one year learns that the client has simultaneously been seeing another therapist for the same condition. The client did not disclose this at intake or during treatment. The therapist discovers this when the other provider contacts them seeking to coordinate care.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 10 provision is most directly relevant?

options.text: Concurrent treatment for the same condition by two providers can create conflicting treatment plans and confuse the client
The client's non-disclosure raises questions about trust and the therapeutic relationship
Uncoordinated PTSD treatments could potentially be harmful, especially if different trauma processing techniques are used simultaneously
The other therapist is stealing the psychologist's client and should be reported
Discuss the concurrent treatment openly with the client, exploring reasons for seeking two providers
With the client's consent, coordinate with the other provider to ensure treatments are complementary, not conflicting
Immediately terminate the client for being dishonest
Collaboratively determine the best arrangement that serves the client's welfare, which may include one provider taking the lead on PTSD treatment

centerOptions.text: Standard 10.04: Providing Therapy to Those Served by Others
Standard 10.05: Sexual Intimacies With Current Clients

questions.explanation: Standard 10.04 (Providing Therapy to Those Served by Others) is most relevant. This standard requires psychologists to carefully consider treatment issues and the potential client's welfare when deciding to provide services to someone already receiving mental health services elsewhere. Although the psychologist did not initially know about the concurrent treatment, upon learning of it, they have an obligation to address it. The appropriate response is to discuss the situation openly with the client, coordinate with the other provider when authorized, and determine an arrangement that best serves the client's welfare. Immediate punitive termination would not serve the client's interests.

questions.stem: A clinical psychology intern is studying Standard 10 for the EPPP. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about therapy ethics:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 10.01 requires psychologists to obtain informed consent to therapy as early as feasible, including information about the nature of therapy, fees, and limits of confidentiality. (B) Psychologists may engage in sexual relationships with current therapy clients as long as both parties consent and the relationship is documented. (C) Standard 10.02 requires psychologists doing couples or family therapy to clarify at the outset which individuals are clients and the probable uses of information obtained. (D) Standard 10.10 permits psychologists to abruptly abandon therapy clients at any time without providing referrals or pre-termination counseling. (E) Standard 10.03 requires psychologists providing group therapy to describe at the outset the roles and responsibilities of all parties and the limits of confidentiality. (F) Standard 10.08 permits sexual intimacies with former therapy clients after a minimum two-year waiting period, but only under the most unusual circumstances and the psychologist bears the burden of demonstrating no exploitation. (G) Standard 10.04 allows psychologists to immediately begin treating anyone regardless of whether they are already receiving services from another provider. (H) Standard 10.07 permits psychologists to accept as therapy clients persons with whom they have previously had sexual relationships.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 10.01 requires comprehensive informed consent; (C) Standard 10.02 requires clarification of client identity and information use in couples/family therapy; (E) Standard 10.03 addresses group therapy obligations; (F) Standard 10.08 establishes the two-year minimum and unusual circumstances requirement. Incorrect: (B) Sexual relationships with current clients are absolutely prohibited (10.05); (D) Termination requires pre-termination counseling and referrals (10.10); (G) Providing therapy to those served by others requires careful consideration (10.04); (H) Psychologists may NOT accept as therapy clients persons with whom they have had sexual relationships (10.07).

questions.stem: A psychologist is reviewing Standards 10.05 through 10.08 regarding sexual boundaries in therapy. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 10.05 prohibits sexual intimacies with current therapy clients regardless of whether the client consents, because the power differential makes genuine consent impossible. (B) Standard 10.06 permits sexual intimacies with the relatives and significant others of current therapy clients as long as the sexual relationship does not directly involve the client. (C) Standard 10.07 prohibits psychologists from accepting as therapy clients persons with whom they have engaged in sexual intimacies, because the prior sexual relationship would compromise objective treatment. (D) The two-year waiting period in Standard 10.08 is merely a suggestion, and psychologists may use their clinical judgment to pursue relationships with former clients at any time. (E) Under Standard 10.08, even after the two-year minimum has elapsed, the psychologist bears the burden of demonstrating that the relationship is not exploitative, considering factors such as the nature of therapy, time elapsed, client vulnerability, and circumstances of termination. (F) Sexual intimacies with former clients are automatically ethical once two years have passed since termination.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 10.05 absolutely prohibits sexual intimacies with current clients, recognizing that the power differential fundamentally compromises consent; (C) Standard 10.07 prohibits accepting former sexual partners as clients because the prior relationship would compromise therapeutic objectivity; (E) Standard 10.08(b) places the burden on the psychologist to demonstrate no exploitation, considering multiple factors. Incorrect: (B) Standard 10.06 prohibits sexual intimacies with relatives/significant others of current clients; (D) The two-year period is a mandatory minimum, not a suggestion; (F) The passage of two years alone does not make the relationship ethical — it must meet the 'most unusual circumstances' standard.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of an ethically sound therapy termination process in the correct order:

options.text: Provide appropriate referrals to other service providers if the client may benefit from additional or different services
Assess whether the client has met treatment goals or whether continued therapy is indicated
Document the termination process, including the rationale, client's response, and referral information provided
Engage in pre-termination counseling that reviews progress, reinforces gains, and addresses the client's feelings about ending treatment
Discuss the possibility of termination with the client and collaboratively evaluate readiness

questions.explanation: Ethical termination follows a structured process: First, the psychologist assesses whether treatment goals have been met or continued therapy is warranted (Standard 10.10(a)). Then, the psychologist discusses the possibility of termination with the client, making it a collaborative process. Pre-termination counseling follows (Standard 10.10(c)), addressing progress, gains, and the client's feelings. Referrals are provided as needed. Finally, thorough documentation captures the termination process, rationale, and referral information. This sequence ensures that termination is thoughtful, client-centered, and properly documented.

questions.stem: Arrange the factors a psychologist should consider when evaluating whether a post-termination sexual relationship with a former client would constitute exploitation under Standard 10.08, from most to least important:

options.text: The former client's current mental status and vulnerability
The nature, duration, and intensity of the therapy
Whether the therapist suggested the possibility of a post-termination relationship during therapy
The amount of time that has passed since termination
The circumstances surrounding the termination of therapy

questions.explanation: Standard 10.08(b) lists factors for evaluating post-termination sexual relationships. Most critical: whether the therapist suggested or implied a future relationship during therapy (opt3) — this virtually always indicates exploitation because it means therapy was being used as a prelude to a sexual relationship. Next, the nature, duration, and intensity of therapy (opt2) — deeper, longer therapy creates stronger transference and vulnerability. The client's current mental status and vulnerability (opt1) directly indicates exploitation risk. Circumstances of termination (opt5) — was it clinician-initiated with a hidden agenda? Finally, while time elapsed (opt4) matters (minimum 2 years), it is the least important factor because mere passage of time does not eliminate the impact of the therapeutic relationship.

questions.stem: A state ethics committee tracks the types of therapy-related ethical complaints received over a decade:

questions.question: What pattern is most notable in the data over the decade?

options.text: All categories have decreased equally
Boundary violation complaints have decreased while termination and informed consent complaints have increased, suggesting a shift in the nature of ethical challenges facing therapists
Sexual misconduct remains the dominant complaint
No meaningful trends are apparent

questions.question: What likely explains the increase in improper termination complaints after 2019?

options.text: Psychologists have become less competent at termination
The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted ongoing therapy relationships through practice closures, insurance changes, and provider relocations, leading to more abrupt or poorly managed terminations
Clients have become more dependent on therapy
Termination standards have become more lenient

questions.explanation: The data reveal an encouraging decline in sexual boundary violation complaints (35% to 18%), suggesting that decades of emphasis on boundary education in training programs has been effective. However, termination (20% to 35%) and informed consent (15% to 30%) complaints have risen significantly. The post-2019 spike in termination complaints likely reflects COVID-19's disruption of therapeutic relationships — practice closures, insurance disruptions, therapist relocations, and transitions to telehealth that some clients could not access. These trends suggest that while the profession has improved in preventing the most egregious boundary violations, it must now address the more subtle but equally important ethical challenges of proper termination and comprehensive informed consent.

questions.stem: A telehealth therapy platform tracks informed consent completion rates and client satisfaction with the consent process over five years:

datasets.name: Clients reporting understanding of confidentiality limits (%)

questions.question: What does the initial low rate of telehealth-specific risk awareness (20% in 2020) suggest?

options.text: Telehealth risks are not important enough to discuss with clients

The rapid adoption of telehealth during the pandemic outpaced the development of telehealth-specific informed consent procedures, leaving many clients uninformed about unique risks such as electronic security, privacy in home settings, and technology failures
Clients do not care about telehealth risks
Telehealth has no unique risks compared to in-person therapy

questions.question: What does the consistent improvement across all metrics suggest?

options.text: Clients are becoming easier to work with
Systematic efforts to develop and implement comprehensive telehealth informed consent procedures under Standard 10.01 have been effective
Informed consent is no longer necessary for telehealth
The improvements are coincidental and unrelated to practice changes

questions.explanation: The data show dramatic improvement in telehealth informed consent practices from 2020 to 2024. The initially low rates reflect the emergency adoption of telehealth during the pandemic, when many practitioners transitioned to virtual care without adequate preparation for telehealth-specific informed consent. Standard 10.01 requires informed consent that includes the nature of services and limits of confidentiality — in a telehealth context, this must address electronic security, the inability to guarantee privacy in the client's environment, technology failure protocols, and emergency procedures when provider and client are in different locations. The consistent improvement suggests the profession has systematically developed and implemented better telehealth consent procedures.

questions.stem: Categorize each therapy situation as either ethically permissible or a violation under Standard 10:

items.text: A psychologist terminates therapy with a client who has achieved their treatment goals, after providing pre-termination counseling and referrals (10.10)
A psychologist begins a sexual relationship with a current therapy client who expresses romantic interest (10.05)
A psychologist clarifies at the outset of couples therapy which individuals are clients and how individual disclosures will be handled (10.02)
A psychologist accepts a former sexual partner as a therapy client (10.07)
A psychologist providing group therapy describes the roles and responsibilities of all parties and the limits of confidentiality at the outset (10.03)
A psychologist abruptly terminates a high-risk client due to insurance expiration without providing referrals, safety planning, or pre-termination counseling (10.10)

questions.explanation: Permissible: Proper termination with pre-termination counseling and referrals (item1, compliant with 10.10); clarifying roles at outset of couples therapy (item3, compliant with 10.02); and describing group therapy obligations at outset (item5, compliant with 10.03). Violations: Sexual relationship with current client (item2, violates 10.05); accepting former sexual partner as client (item4, violates 10.07); and abandoning a high-risk client without proper termination procedures (item6, violates 10.10). Each violation represents a fundamental breach of the therapist's ethical obligations to client welfare.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario according to the most relevant Standard 10 provision:

categories.label: Standard 10.01/10.02: Informed Consent and Role Clarification

items.text: A psychologist discusses the nature of therapy, fees, and confidentiality limits with a new client before beginning treatment
A psychologist initiates a romantic relationship with a former client one year after termination
A psychologist relocating to another state provides three months' notice, referrals, and a warm transfer to a new provider
A psychologist in couples therapy establishes a no-secrets policy and clarifies the roles of each participant at intake
A psychologist terminates therapy with a client who no longer needs services, providing pre-termination counseling and community resources
A psychologist begins a sexual relationship with the sibling of a current therapy client

questions.explanation: Standard 10.01/10.02: Discussing therapy elements with a new client (item1, Standard 10.01 informed consent) and establishing policies in couples therapy (item4, Standard 10.02 role clarification). Standard 10.05-10.08: Romantic relationship with former client at one year (item2, violates Standard 10.08's two-year minimum) and sexual relationship with current client's sibling (item6, violates Standard 10.06). Standard 10.09/10.10: Planned relocation with proper transition (item3, Standard 10.09 interruption of therapy) and appropriate termination process (item5, Standard 10.10).
